Soy protein isolate and its effects on breast cancer

Summary generated using: $shovel3 query.concatConclusions 'breast cancer soy protein isolate site:ncbi.nlm.nih.gov' 40 includeReference=True
  • SPI may protect against cancer via multiple mechanisms, including: 1) increased mammary gland differentiation, 2) decreased activation of procarcinogens to carcinogens and 3) regulation of genes in signal transduction pathways underlying tumor initiation, promotion and/or progression.
    • Journal:
    • Date:
    • Link to article
  • Soy consumption may be associated with reduced risk of breast cancer incidence, recurrence, and mortality. Soy does not have estrogenic effects in humans. Soy intake consistent with a traditional Japanese diet appears safe for breast cancer survivors. While there is no clear evidence of harm, better evidence confirming safety is required before use of high dose (≥100mg) isoflavones can be recommended for breast cancer patients.
    • Journal:
    • Date:
    • Link to article
  • Our study suggests that the isoflavone intake of breast cancer patients at our hospital was quite variable. Thirty-five patients reported no soy intake. The mean daily intake of 11.6 mg genistein and 7.4 mg daidzein, is the equivalent of less than 1/4 cup of tofu per day. This amount is higher than what has been previously reported in non-Asian American women.
    • Journal:
    • Date:
    • Link to article
  • These data suggest that short-term, moderate consumption of isoflavone-containing soy protein and consumption of these particular probiotic capsules do not significantly alter reproductive hormone concentrations in breast cancer survivors or controls, regardless of equol producer status.
    • Journal:
    • Date:
    • Link to article
  • Long-term consumption of low GEN doses (≤500 ppm) promotes MCF-7 tumor growth and results in GINR tumors with more aggressive and advanced growth phenotypes. © 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.
    • Journal: Molecular Nutrition & Food Research
    • Date: 03/02/15
